No development shall take place until a Construction Logistics Plan (CLP) has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The CLP shall set out the measures proposed to ensure construction will be undertaken in a manner which does not cause harm to the amenity of nearby occupiers, pedestrian or highway safety and shall include:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.(l) A scheme for recycling/disposing of waste resulting from demolition and  construction works.The development shall be carried out strictly in accordance with the approved CLP throughout the construction period.REASON: The relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to commencement of any development on site, a Construction Management Plan shall be submitted to the planning authority for written agreement. The development shall only be implemented in accordance with the details and measures approved as part of the construction management plan, which shall be maintained throughout the entire construction period.The Construction Management Plan shall include:-Construction details of the hotel building-Setting out delivery vehicle management, to include timings and stacking capacity- A commitment that no construction related deliveries to the site will be undertaken during peak periods (08:00 - 09:00 and 16:30 - 18:00);- Information on Origin & Destination (O&D) (i.e. muck away, concrete, vehicle class and frequencies etc);- Use of a delivery booking system to ensure vehicles can be accommodated on site;- Plans highlighting the allocation of holding and utility areas for the construction vehicles, to prevent any vehicles which cannot be accommodated on site from waiting on the surrounding roads; and- Advance notice on when cranes and hoardings will be arriving on site and also information on advance utility routing and requirements, for the purposes of traffic management.Reason: The relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the commencement of the development, a Construction Environmental Management Plan outlining the mitigation measures to minimise release of dust entering the atmosphere or being deposited on nearby receptors, particularly during construction activities, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.The plan will need to consider mitigation measures designed to limit emissions from vehicles used in connection with the development, including the use of low emission plant and vehicles (ideally Euro V emission standard or better) fitted with catalysts, diesel particulate filters or similar devices in respect of both on road and off road vehicles and plant. The development shall be carried out strictly in accordance with the details so approved and no change therefrom shall take place without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.REASON: The relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in the interests of sustainability and energy conservation as set out in Policies 5.2 and 5.3 of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved, a Delivery and Servicing Management Plan shall be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority.  The scheme shall include the following details:- How delivery vehicles and servicing will be managed at the sites;- The hours of deliveries and servicing;- How deliveries will be controlled to ensure the development does not adversely affect the highway;-An explanation of the controls on the types and sizes of vehicles accessing the site to ensure they are appropriate to the local area and environmentally acceptable in terms of exhaust and noise emissionsThe development shall be carried out strictly in accordance with the details so approved and shall be maintained as such thereafter.REASON: In the interests of highway safety and to ensure that the proposed development does not prejudice the free flow of traffic or conditions of general safety on adjoining highways and that adequate servicing and manoeuvring provision is made in accordance with Policies DM9 and Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall take place until an investigation and risk assessment, in addition to any assessment provided with the planning application, and has been completed in accordance with a scheme to assess the nature and extent of any contamination on the site, whether or not it originates on the site. The contents of the scheme should be submitted to and be approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The investigation and risk assessment must be undertaken by competent persons and a written report of the findings must be produced. The written report is subject to the approval in writing of the Local Planning Authority. The report of the findings must include:(i) a survey of the extent, scale and nature of contamination; (ii) an assessment of the potential risks to:o human health,o property (existing or proposed) including buildings, crops, livestock, pets, woodland and service lines and pipes,o adjoining land,o groundwaters and surface waters,o ecological systems,o archaeological sites and ancient monuments;(iii) an appraisal of remedial options, and proposal of the preferred option(s).This must be conducted in accordance with DEFRA and the Environment Agency's 'Model Procedures for the Management of Land Contamination, CLR 11.Reason: To ensure that risks from land contamination is understood prior to works on site both during the construction phase to the future users of the land and neighbouring land are minimised, together with those to controlled waters, property and ecological systems, and to ensure that the development can be carried out safely without unacceptable risks to workers, neighbours and other offsite receptors in accordance with Policies DM10.

Application SiteThe  application relates to the ground floor commercial unit specifically and is located within the designated Tolworth District Centre.The proposal seeks to subdivide the existing pawn brokers unit to maintain a pawn brokers and introduce a bakery with tables and chairs outside on the pavement and to the front of the premises.Located in the main commercial street of Tolworth District Centre the proposal is considered to be compatible with its surroundings. There have been no objections to the application received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light, loss of privacy, visual intrusion or noise.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted.The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks a change to the approved roof form from a crown design to a fully hipped design. Officers are satisfied that this would have a negligible impact on the character and appearance of the area and would constitute a non-material amendment.However, it is proposed to substitute drawing 2671-RDJWL-ZZ-ZZ-DR-A-0025, which shows the approved site layout / ground floor plan and first floor plan, as well as all four elevations of the building, with drawings 2671-RDJWL-01-ZZ-DR-A-0077 and 2671-RDJWL-01-XX-DR-A-0076, which show only three elevations of the building and do not show any floor plans or site layout. Doing so would result in an incomplete set of plans and therefore the application should be refused in the interests of proper planning.

The site comprises a flat within a terraced property. The application site is located within St. Andrews Square Conservation Area.51 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 representation in support of the application has been received. Kingston Town Neighbourhood CAAC - No objectionThe key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and, - The impact to St. Andrews Square Conservation Area.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form and design. It is considered that the proposed rooflights would be in keeping with the features of the original property and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the size and positioning of the rooflights and the separation distances between neighbouring properties it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC 1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: The application site falls within St. Andrews Square Conservation Area. The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as an area of Victorian housing dating from the 1860s - 1880s, in Gothic and Classical styles, including a garden square unique to South West London. It forms a later phase of the Surbiton "New Town" begun in 1838 by Thomas Pooley.Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the significance of the St. Andrews Square Conservation Area, but rather preserve it. As previously mentioned, the proposed development would be in keeping with features of the original property and the character of the immediate surrounding area. Given no harm to heritage assets has been identified in this case, it is not necessary to weigh up the proposals against any public benefits.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

---OFFICER REPORT---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalThe application seeks a variation to the plans approved under 20/00415/HOU to provide a change to the form and design of the single storey rear extension, a change to the size of the crown roof, and alterations to the fenestration in the rear elevation.Consultation4 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.Kingston Town CAAC - Objection on the grounds of design and harm to the significance of the neighbouring grade II listed church.Officer Response: Design and heritage assets will be considered below. While this is, in effect, a fresh application for the entire development, the principle of the development has nevertheless already been established. On such an application, the local planning authority may only consider the conditions subject to which permission should be granted. It would therefore be unnecessary and unreasonable to revisit every issue which was relevant to the determination of the original application.In assessing the application, officers are mindful of any changes in planning policy or site circumstances since the granting of the original permission.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposed amendments would see the size of the crown roof increase but not to the extent that it would be readily appreciable from any public vantage points. The approved rear extension would reduce in overall scale and the mono-pitch roof would be replaced by one of a fully hipped design, which would respond better to the design of the dwelling as a whole. In the absence of any material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal---END OF OFFICER REPORT---

The proposed building referred to is the subject of another planning application 21/01615/HOU pending consideration, and does not form part of this application. -Maldens and Coombe Conservation Area Advisory Committee (CAAC)-No objection-RBK Tree and Landscape Officer-No objection AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area- The impact of the development on heritage assets; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposal is a revised and reduced version of the approved scheme 20/01152/HOU. The overall scale, layout and design of the approved scheme would be the same as approved with the exception of the basement which has been removed. The additional windows proposed, given their location and design are t considered not to detract or harm the appearance of the property when viewed from any neighbouring properties or the street. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would have a positive impact on the character and appearance of the area.Heritage AssetsSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.The site is located within the Liverpool Road Conservation Area. The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as an area of individually designed detached and semi-detached houses dating from the 1850s set in a mature landscape on the edge of Richmond Park.As stated above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area would be acceptable. Furthermore, the Maldens and Coombe CAAC raise no objection to the proposals. Given this, officers are satisfied that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the significance of the conservation area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers are satisfied that the scale and siting of the proposed extensions are such that they would not appear overbearing or unduly deprive neighbouring occupiers of natural light. The proposed side facing roof lights may give rise to unacceptable views over 22 Liverpool Road but this could be effectively mitigated by a condition requiring obscure glazing. The remaining windows would offer similar views to those already available from the property.It is noted that air conditioning units would be positioned towards the bottom of the rear garden within a timber clad enclosure. In the event of an approval, a condition would be secured requiring the units to be at least 5dB below the background level.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable.Other Matters:An Arboricultural Method Statement and Construction Method Statement, has been submitted in support of the application. The Council's Tree Officer has raised no objection to the proposal, subject to recommended conditions including the submission of a landscaping plan prior to commencement of works. The proposal is, therefore, considered to be compliant with Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy, with regards to the impact to trees.ConclusionThe proposed development would have a positive impact on the character and appearance of the area, principally by restoring balance to the pair of semi-detached properties of which the application property forms part. It would not result in any harm to the significance of heritage assets.Officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable. Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.

---OFFICER REPORT---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling.ProposalThe application seeks the erection of a part single, part two storey rear extension, the erection of railings to the front boundary, the insertion of replacement windows, and a change to the location of the front door.Consultation20 properties were notified of the proposal. 2 objections were received. The material issues raised are summarised as follows:- Overbearing appearance;- Loss of light;- Loss of privacy; and,- Harm to the character and appearance of the area.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area;- The impact of the development on heritage assets; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The single storey element of the proposed rear extension would extend across the entirety of the rear elevation to a depth of 4m, rising to a maximum height of 3.36m above ground level. The two storey element of the proposed rear extension would also extend across the entirety of the rear elevation but would measure 1.15m in depth. Its roof would effectively extend the existing rear roof slope, albeit with a slightly shallower pitch. Officers note that the Council's Residential Design SPD states that single storey extensions should generally not exceed 3m to 3.5m in depth and those with parapet roofs should not exceed 3.3m in height. The proposed rear extension would exceed these dimensions and would appear even taller when viewed from No. 26A Clifton Road, since the land falls by approximately 300mm towards this property. The Residential Design SPD suggests that in these circumstances, the depth of a rear extension should be reduced.However, the Residential Design SPD also states that if a neighbouring property has a different rear building line, then the depth of the extension could be increased. No. 26A Clifton Road does indeed have a different rear building line and the proposed single storey element would project only approximately 3m beyond this. Furthermore, the extension would be set off the shared boundary by approximately 1m. Turning to the other adjoining neighbour, No. 30 Clifton Road, the proposed single storey element would be set hard up against the shared boundary. However, it would only project beyond the rear building line of this property by approximately 200mm.At first floor level, the proposed extension would project beyond the rear building line of No. 26A Clifton Road by approximately 1.6m. However, it would again benefit from approximately 1m of separation from the shared boundary. To the other side, the extension would match the rear building line of 30 Clifton Road.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed extensions would not appear cramped or otherwise represent an overdevelopment of the site. They would appear as proportionate and subordinate extensions to the dwelling and would not appear out of scale with neighbouring properties. The alterations to the front of the property would see the existing aluminium sash windows replaced by metal-clad timber casements. The front door would be brought forward, resulting in the loss of the front porch, although the distinctive brick arch would be retained. A set of black painted wrought iron railings and gates, with brick piers, would be erected along the front boundary of the site.Although the loss of the sash windows would be somewhat regrettable, officers recognise the prevalence of casement windows in the area, including many lower quality uPVC designs. Given this, officers consider that the change would have a very limited impact on the overall character and appearance of the area. Likewise, officers consider that the relocation of the front door would have a very limited impact, especially since the brick arch would be retained.It is recognised that timber fences and low brick walls are more typical means of enclosure for the area. However, there are some limited examples of metal railings and these do not detract from the character or appearance of the area. As such, officers consider that the railings and gates currently proposed would have an acceptable impact.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the overall impact of the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area would be acceptable.HeritageParagraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance. The site is located just outside of the boundary of the Park Road Conservation Area. The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as an area of fine Victorian houses and local shops dating from 1890 -1900.Given that the application property is recognisably modern, and noting that the impact of the development on the character and appearance would be acceptable, officers consider that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the significance of the conservation area. It is therefore not necessary to weigh up the public benefits of the proposal.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The spatial relationship between the proposed extensions and neighbouring properties has been discussed at length above and in the interests of brevity will not be reiterated. Although the land falls from the site towards No. 26A Clifton Road, officers consider that the extent to which the proposed extensions would project beyond the rear building lines of this property (at both ground and first floors), as well as the degree of separation from the shared boundary, would be such that the extensions would not appear overbearing. Officers reach the same conclusion in respect of No. 30 Clifton Road, although separation is not a factor here, since the extensions would be set hard up against the shared boundary.With regard to natural light, officers note that the proposed extensions would pass the 45 degree test as set out in the Residential Design SPD. This indicates that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on daylight. Land levels are again relevant in respect of No. 26A Clifton Road, but again any effect would be offset by the degree of separation between the extensions and the shared boundary.With regard to privacy, officers note that the proposal would not involve the insertion of any new side facing windows at first floor level or above. However, the existing windows would be replaced and it is therefore necessary to impose a condition requiring obscure glazing. New side facing windows would be inserted at ground floor level and although it is not normally necessary to impose conditions on these, in light of the differing land levels between the site and NO. 26A Clifton Road, a similar obscure glazing condition is considered to be necessary here.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development, subject to conditions, would have an acceptable impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.ConclusionThe proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area and on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. It would not have any impact on the significance of heritage assets.Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal---END OF OFFICER REPORT---
